prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for yelling at someone else’s kid
Yesterday was Christmas and all of my family was in my parents house with their kids. A little background I have a 7yr son who has mild autism which makes it a little hard for him to fit in with the other kids. Ok back to the story, at one point in the day my cousin’s daughter 13yr was messing with my son by taking his toys that my mother keeps in the house for him and hiding them from him which made him upset. And later on she started making me made by telling my sister’s kids that my son was a, ”Retard.” Then came to me nudged me and said, “Is your son a retard so I snapped and yelled at this kid, “YOU CAN’T CALL MY SON A RETARD!” All of my family members of course heard me, and the girl started crying. Her mom get mad at me for, “Using that language around her.” And I was blowing up inside so much that I couldn’t stay so I grabbed my son and husband and walked out with every watching.

It feels good writing this down and I just want a little feedback on if that was the write thing to do which I know it wasn’t.
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is that the author's cousin's daughter was messing with the author's son, who has mild autism. The girl hid his toys and then made a derogatory comment about his son, calling him a "retard." The author snapped and yelled at the girl, which caused her to cry and her mom got angry because of the language used. The author then left the situation.

First, I need to consider the context. The son has autism, which can make social interactions challenging. The cousin's daughter's actions might be bullying or teasing, which is harmful, especially to a child with special needs. The author's reaction is understandable from a protective parent perspective. However, yelling in front of others and using strong language might not be the best approach, even if the provocation was hurtful.

The mom of the other child was upset because of the language. The term "retard" is offensive and derogatory, even if the author was reacting to the girl using that word. So, by yelling that, the author might be seen as using that language as well, which could explain the other mom's anger. But the author was reacting to the girl's use of the slur. The question is whether the author's response was proportionate.

On one hand, defending one's child from being bullied is important. On the other hand, the method of response—yelling loudly in front of the family, which led to the other child crying and the family tension—might have escalated the situation. The author walked out, which could be seen as avoiding the conflict but also protecting their child from a stressful environment.

In terms of right or wrong, it's a bit of a gray area. The author had a valid reason to be upset, but the manner of the response could have been handled differently. Maybe addressing the issue calmly with the other parent or the girl's mom would have been better. So, considering the context, the author's intentions were protective, but the execution might be seen as inappropriate. Therefore, the answer might be A (the author is in the wrong) because while the reaction is understandable, yelling in that manner and using that language could be seen as crossing a line, even if provoked.
